Award.AwardTitle: CSEDI Collaborative Research: Anelastic properties of the Earth from seismic to tidal timescale
Award.AbstractNarration:
Earthquakes produce sound waves that travel through the interior of the Earth and thereby sample the conditions along their paths. Collections of large numbers of arriving sound waves are used to reconstruct conditions and structure of the interior of the Earth. While traveling through the interior, these waves produce microscopic strains in the rocks they pass through. The response of the rocks to these strains depends on conditions such as temperature and chemical environment. Very large Earthquakes in subduction zones, for example the Andaman-Sumatra earthquake from 2004 or the Alaskan earthquake from 1964, produce enough energy for the Earth to "ring like a bell". Gravitational interaction of the Earth with the Moon and the Sun (tides) causes periodic deformation of the whole Earth that is comparable to the effects of large Earthquakes. Microscopic strains similar to those caused by earthquakes and tides can be investigated in the laboratory, and thereby also the effects of temperature and chemical environment on the response. The challenge of the proposed work is to apply the laboratory results to global observations from seismology and geodesy. The promise of this approach is to improve our understanding of the conditions in the interior of the Earth and its physical description. The findings will have implications for modeling of the ongoing rebound of the surface of the Earth since the last ice age, affecting determination of the causes of changes in sea level, as well as tidal modeling of other planets and moons.

The investigators propose to combine observations of small-strain deformation at a broad range of timescales, from seismic body waves (seconds) to normal modes (minutes - hour) and tides (hours to years), to determine the frequency dependence of energy dissipation in the interior of the Earth. These observations will be combined in a normal mode/tidal model of a non-spherical Earth that includes anelasticity. Results from this model will be compared to laboratory-derived models for anelastic behavior of crystalline grains and their defects, which are the basis for predictions outside of the experimentally accessible parameter space. Comparison of experimental predictions with global models will help to constrain the applicability of the microphysical models to small-strain deformation due to seismic waves and tides, and ultimately also post-glacial rebound and (large-strain) convection. At the same time the combination of information from normal modes and tides will yield new constraints on the conditions and structure in the mid to lower mantle, which are difficult to obtain by other means.

ProgramElement.Text: STUDIES OF THE EARTHS DEEP INT

POR.DRECONTENT:
The deep interior of the Earth is inaccessible to direct observation. Information is obtained through indirect means such as measuring the speed of sound from an earthquake to receivers (seismometers) distributed at the surface of the Earth. Very large Earthquakes in subduction zones, for example the Andaman-Sumatra earthquake from 2004, or the Alaskan earthquake from 1964 produce enough energy for the Earth to ?ring like a bell?. This means the earthquakes produce standing waves or normal modes, slightly distorting the Earth?s shape. Due to the rotation of the Earth, it deviates slightly from spherical with a shorter diameter between the poles compared to the equator. Similar distortions are caused by gravitational interactions with the Moon and the Sun, resulting in solid body tides. These can be measured geodetically by high precision GPS measurements. A key difference between normal modes and tides is the period at which they occur: from minutes to a little less than one hour for modes, and one month to 16.8 years for tides. Modes and tides are measured by different means (seismometers vs GPS) and have been interpreted based on different theoretical approaches by the respective communities. This lead to contradictory models of the behavior and therefore physical state of the interior of the Earth, and in particular the Earth?s lower mantle.

Microscopic stresses similar to those caused by earthquakes and tides can be investigated in the laboratory, and thereby also the effects of temperature and chemical environment on the resulting micro-strains. The micro-strains result in anelastic behavior characterized by time-dependence (like viscous strain) and recoverability of the strain (like elastic strains). The time (frequency) dependence of anelastic strain is, however, distinct from that of viscous strain. The original laboratory experiments were carried out on upper mantle minerals at periods relevant for body and surface waves (seconds to 1000 s). We adapted the fit to this laboratory data for extension to longer time scales and the mineralogy of the lower mantle, guided by convection models of the Earth. Next, a mathematical theory was further developed that enabled self-consistent treatment of a non-spherical, self gravitating, anelastic Earth?s distortions due to both normal modes and solid Earth tides. The selected set of modes and tides range over six orders of magnitude in period but have similar depth sensitivity. Previous seismic studies suffered from intrinsic coupling of depth resolution and period, which can not be resolved independently by these studies.

Forward modeling employing the new theory and the adapted experimental fit showed that with reasonable parameter ranges the Earth?s response to both normal modes and tides can be explained self-consistently by a single set of models and parameters. This reconciles the seemingly contradictory conclusions from separate seismic and geodetic studies. In particular we were able to explain the different period dependence of the response to modes relative to tides with the adapted experimental fit. This serves as further support of the underlying microphysical model for application to processes with longer timescales such as postglacial rebound, allowing for example improved modeling of changes in sea level. The model can also be used to improve accuracy of GPS data by forward modeling of Earth?s response to modes and tides. The study yielded new constraints on the conditions and structure of Earth?s mid to lower mantle, which are difficult to obtain by other means. The model developed here can also be applied to the tides of other planets and moons.

We also started reanalyzing the experimental samples used in the Burgers model fit taking advantage of the analytical capabilities of the new scanning electron microscope.
